message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, such as shortness of breath, chronic sinusitis, foot drop, and subcutaneous nodules, suggest the most likely diagnosis is eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), previously known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. The high eosinophil count, red blood cell casts, and elevated serum creatinine also support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of asthma and foot drop, and the physical examination shows diffuse wheezing and tender subcutaneous nodules. Laboratory studies show a high eosinophil count and red blood cell casts in urine microscopy. These findings are strongly suggestive of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms consistent with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA, formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome), including asthma, chronic sinusitis, peripheral neuropathy (foot drop), and subcutaneous nodules. The elevated eosinophil count and red blood cell casts are also characteristic of EGPA. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis usually do not present with prominent eosinophilia. Polyarteritis nodosa does not typically involve the lungs or cause asthma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of eosinophils, subcutaneous nodules, and renal involvement with red blood cell casts suggest eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA), also known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis and microscopic polyangiitis may involve the lungs, but they are less likely to have eosinophilia as a prominent feature. Polyarteritis nodosa typically presents with systemic symptoms and renal involvement, but not with eosinophilia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, also known as Churg-Strauss syndrome. The presence of tender subcutaneous nodules, a leukocyte count with eosinophilia, and red blood cell casts in urine all support this diagnosis. All other options may involve systemic vasculitis but are less likely to present with these specific findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of asthma and sinusitis, and presents with progressive shortness of breath, cough, and tender subcutaneous nodules on both elbows. Laboratory studies show a high level of eosinophils and red blood cell casts in urine microscopy, indicating kidney involvement. All these symptoms point toward the diagnosis of eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a history of asthma, chronic sinusitis, and foot drop, which are all associated with Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). The presence of subcutaneous nodules, leukocytosis with eosinophilia, and red blood cell casts in urine microscopy support the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of asthma, chronic sinusitis, foot drop, subcutaneous nodules, elevated eosinophils, and red blood cell casts suggest the most likely diagnosis is Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). Other options may also present with respiratory symptoms and systemic involvement but may not have the specific combination of findings seen in the patient.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of subcutaneous nodules and asthma suggests Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Churg-Strauss syndrome). The elevated eosinophil count and red blood cell casts in urine also support this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including asthma, chronic sinusitis, foot drop, subcutaneous nodules, high eosinophil count, and red blood cell casts, suggest the most likely diagnosis is Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis may present with similar symptoms but without high eosinophil count and red blood cell casts. Microscopic polyangiitis may show little to no signs of asthma or eosinophilia. Polyarteritis nodosa is not associated with eosinophilia or red blood cell casts.
